questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of severe pain while passing stools. The stools are covered with bright red blood. He has been avoiding defecation because of the pain. Last year, he was hospitalized for pilonidal sinus surgery. He has chronic lower back pain due to an accident at his workplace 10 years ago. The patient's father was diagnosed with colon cancer at the age of 62 years. Current medications include oxycodone and gabapentin. He is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 38 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Examination of the perianal area reveals a partially visible erythematous tear with smooth edges in the posterior anal midline. There is no discharge or palpable mass. Digital rectal examination cannot be performed because of severe pain. His hemoglobin concentration is 16.3 g/dL and his leukocyte count is 8300/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Botulinum toxin injection into the internal anal sphincter is used for the treatment of anal fissures that are refractory to conservative therapy. This procedure relaxes the hypertonic anal sphincter, but it is not indicated as a first-line treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Tract curettage is a technique used for the treatment of anal fistula. An anal fistula may present with bloody stools and rectal pain, but the condition would be noticeable during examination and have a malodorous perianal discharge.

C) CORRECT:

Conservative measures such as sitz baths and topical therapy with calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine, diltiazem) are recommended as the initial treatment for most anal fissures. These measures reduce anal sphincter tone and promote mucosal healing by increasing blood flow to the anal mucosa.

Additionally, prevention and/or treatment of constipation is central to allowing the fissure to heal. This can be achieved with increased intake of dietary fiber and water, the use of stool softeners and/or laxatives, and, if possible, avoidance of medications that cause constipation (e.g., opioids).

D) INCORRECT:

In patients with a suspected anal fissure, colonoscopy is only indicated if the diagnosis is unclear or if an underlying pathology such as colorectal cancer or inflammatory bowel disease is suspected (e.g., due to atypical features or chronic fissures). Atypical features include multiple fissures and fissures in locations other than the posterior midline. However, this patient has a typical single superficial tear in the anoderm in the posterior midline and has only had symptoms for the past 2 weeks. Moreover, he does not have symptoms indicating malignancy or systemic inflammation (e.g., fever, weight loss, anemia).

Patients with a family history of colorectal cancer in a first-degree relative are candidates for colorectal screening with colonoscopy every 10 years starting at 40 years of age or 10 years before the age of diagnosis of the relative, whichever comes first.

E) INCORRECT:

The combination of metronidazole and ciprofloxacin is recommended for the treatment of an anorectal abscess. An anorectal abscess would present with pain on defecation but would not explain this patient's bloody stools.

F) INCORRECT:

Anal sphincterotomy is a surgical procedure that aims to reduce the tone of the anal sphincter. It involves cutting the internal sphincter muscle, which carries a risk of fecal incontinence and is only indicated if symptoms have not improved after 8–12 weeks of conservative management.
questions.hint: This patient's examination findings, painful defecation, and bleeding are consistent with an acute anal fissure, for which constipation (e.g., due to constipation-inducing medications) is a risk factor.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of anal pain that occurs during defecation and lasts for several hours. She reports that she often strains during defecation and sees bright red blood on toilet paper after wiping. She typically has 3 bowel movements per week. Physical examination shows a longitudinal, perianal tear. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by tissue injury in which of the following locations?

choices.text: Posterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line
Anterior midline of the anal canal, proximal to the pectinate line
Anterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line
Posterior midline of the anal canal, proximal to the pectinate line
Lateral aspect of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Approximately 90% of anal fissures occur at the posterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line (dentate line). The etiology is usually benign and primary in nature, with the most common cause being local trauma (e.g., passing of hard stools due to constipation), persistent diarrhea, vaginal delivery, or anal sex. This predilection for the posterior midline is likely due to poor perfusion to this area. Acute anal fissures typically resolve with conservative management.
Image Description:

A longitudinal section of the anal canal with typical features of an acute anal fissure. A longitudinal tear in the anoderm extending from the dentate line to the anocutaneous line can be seen. The wound margins are smooth, and the surrounding mucosa appears unremarkable.

B) INCORRECT:

The region of the anal canal proximal to the pectinate line is a common location for internal hemorrhoids and adenocarcinoma of the anal canal, whereas anal fissures occur distal to the pectinate line. Internal hemorrhoids are characterized by the passage of bright red blood per rectum with a bowel movement. However, defecation is usually painless.

C) INCORRECT:

Only 10% of anal fissures occur at the anterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line. Anal fissures at this location are usually secondary to anal surgery, IBD (e.g., Crohn disease), infections (e.g., syphilis) or malignancy (leukemia). There is no evidence of an underlying condition in this patient that would make an anal fissure at an atypical location likely.

D) INCORRECT:

The region of the anal canal proximal to the pectinate line is a common location for internal hemorrhoids, whereas anal fissures occur distal to the pectinate line. Internal hemorrhoids are characterized by passage of bright red blood per rectum with a bowel movement. However, defecation is usually painless.

E) INCORRECT:

External hemorrhoids arise below the pectinate, often occur at the left lateral aspect of the anal canal (3 o' clock position), are typically painful, and can cause per rectal bleeding. However, external hemorrhoids would be visible as perianal swellings on physical examination. Less than 1% of anal fissures occur at the lateral aspect of the anal canal. Anal fissures that occur at this location are usually secondary to anal surgery, IBD (e.g., Crohn disease), infections (e.g., syphilis) or malignancy (leukemia). There is no evidence of an underlying condition in this patient that would that would make an anal fissure at an atypical location likely.
questions.hint: The region of tissue injury in this patient receives innervation from the inferior rectal branch of the pudendal nerve.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Two months ago, he was diagnosed with an anal fissure and started a high-fiber diet and treatment with lidocaine gel, nifedipine ointment, and daily sitz baths. The patient reports perianal pruritus and sharp anal pain that increases during defecation; he has not had rectal bleeding. Medical history is remarkable for hypercholesterolemia and chronic constipation. His mother was diagnosed with colorectal cancer at the age of 74 years. Medications include atorvastatin and lactulose. He does not smoke cigarettes and drinks two beers daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a deep, longitudinal perianal tear in the posterior midline with wide, raised edges and multiple skin tags. Rectosigmoid endoscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Refer the patient for surgical repair
Continue treatment and schedule follow-up in 4 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sclerotherapy is a treatment option for internal hemorrhoids but has no role in the treatment of anal fissures. Most anal fissures develop in the posterior commissure, which is prone to fissures due to poor perfusion. Sclerosing this vascular space would further delay healing of the fissure. Instead, botulinum toxin injections into the internal anal sphincter may be considered for chronic anal fissures that are refractory to conservative management. Botulinum toxin reduces sphincter spasm, thereby reducing tension on the fissure and allowing it to heal.

B) CORRECT:

Surgery is indicated for patients with chronic anal fissures who do not experience symptom improvement after 8 weeks of conservative management. Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the preferred method as it has lower rates of fecal incontinence than other surgical options.

Botulinum toxin injection into the anal sphincter is a less invasive alternative and may be considered in patients with chronic anal fissures.
Image Description:

A longitudinal section of the anal canal with features of a chronic anal fissure, characterized by a longitudinal ulcerated wound in the anoderm extending from the dentate line to the anocutaneous line. Wound margins commonly show scarring and fibrosis.

Secondary changes commonly associated with chronic fissures are also visible, including a sentinel skin tag at the distal end of the fissure and a hypertrophic anal papilla located proximally near the dentate line, within the region of the anal columns.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy is indicated in patients with anorectal abscess, which can manifest with perianal pruritus and pain that increases during defecation. Physical examination in anorectal abscess shows a fluctuant, indurated mass rather than a deep, longitudinal perianal tear.

D) INCORRECT:

Conservative therapy (e.g., dietary improvement, stool softeners, analgesic creams, sitz baths, topical vasodilators) is the first-line treatment for anal fissures. This patient has persistent symptoms that have not improved with > 8 weeks of conservative therapy, which makes another step in management more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Anoscopy with anal biopsy is used for the diagnosis of anal cancer, which can manifest with anal pain and pruritus. Anal cancer also manifests with rectal bleeding and a lump or tumor around the anus, which are not seen in this patient. This patient has a chronic anal fissure, for which anal biopsy is not indicated at this time.
questions.hint: This patient's anal fissure did not improve with conservative therapy. Anal fissures are considered chronic if they last more than 6–8 weeks.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man reports 2 weeks of persistent perianal pain that worsens with defecation. He also notes small amounts of bright-red blood on the toilet paper after wiping. He reports no abdominal pain or diarrhea. He has not seen any blood in the toilet bowl and reports no anal trauma. Physical examination reveals a superficial linear tear in the posterior anal midline.
Which one of the following approaches is most appropriate for initial management of this patient?

choices.text: Botulinum toxin injection into the anal sphincter
Mesalamine suppositories and a low-residue diet

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anal fissures can be diagnosed on the basis of history and examination findings alone. Patients with anal fissures typically report perianal pain with defecation and can have small amounts of blood on the toilet paper after wiping. Primary anal fissures are usually secondary to trauma; the resulting anal-mucosa tear leads to high sphincter tone or spasm and secondary local ischemia. The increased sphincter tone results in pain, impaired healing, and further tearing of the mucosa with subsequent bowel movements.

Further evaluation of anal fissures is not necessary unless the patient has a nonhealing fissure, multiple fissures, or off-the-midline fissures (most primary anal fissures occur in the posterior anal midline); findings such as this suggest an underlying disease such as Crohn disease, tuberculosis, syphilis, HIV infection, or anal carcinoma.

The most appropriate initial therapy for an acute anal fissure is conservative, aimed at reducing the spasm and preventing further injury. Initial treatment includes warm sitz baths (sitting in water up to the hips) to reduce sphincter tone after defecation and fiber supplementation to soften the stool and prevent constipation.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management for an acute anal fissure is conservative therapy with sitz baths and fiber supplementation.

B) INCORRECT:

Botulinum toxin injection can be used to manage chronic fissures.

C) INCORRECT:

Surgical referral is reserved for patients in whom conservative measures fail.

D) INCORRECT:

Mesalamine suppositories and low-residue diet are used to manage inflammatory bowel disease, not anal fissures.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical nitroglycerin, which increases local blood flow and lowers the anal sphincter pressure, can be effective but has side effects such as headache, so it is not used as first-line therapy.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with sharp anal pain during bowel movements for 2 weeks. The pain is severe and persists for hours after defecation. He occasionally notices bright red blood on the toilet paper. Examination reveals a superficial tear in the posterior midline of the anal canal with a small skin tag. Rectal examination is limited by pain but reveals no mass or abscess.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anal fistulas are characterized by an abnormal tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin, often with purulent drainage. The acute, severe pain and bright red blood are more typical of a superficial tear. The absence of a palpable mass or fluctuance further reduces the likelihood of a fistula.

B) INCORRECT:

A perianal abscess usually presents with a tender, fluctuant mass and surrounding erythema, which are absent here. While pain is common, the lack of a palpable mass or signs of infection, such as induration or fluctuance, makes an abscess unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

External hemorrhoids typically present as swollen, tender, bluish nodules at the anal margin, often due to thrombosis. They do not usually cause persistent, sharp pain after defecation or involve a linear tear. The presence of a superficial tear and skin tag is more indicative of an anal fissure.

D) CORRECT:

Anal fissures manifest with severe, sharp pain during and after defecation, accompanied by minor bright red bleeding. These fissures are tears in the anoderm, commonly located in the posterior midline due to reduced blood supply. The pain is exacerbated by internal anal sphincter spasm, which persists post-defecation. The presence of a superficial tear and a small skin tag suggests both acute inflammation and potential chronicity, characteristic of anal fissures.

Key learning point: Linear cracks in the perianal region, especially at the 6 and 12 o'clock positions, are characteristic of anal fissures, which are often associated with severe pain during bowel movements.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old man presents with persistent anal pain during defecation and bright red blood on toilet paper for five months. He has tried sitz baths, a high-fiber diet, and topical diltiazem with only slight improvement. He has no significant comorbidities. Examination reveals a posterior midline tear with granulation at the edges and a high anal sphincter tone.
Which of the following is the most appropriate surgical intervention for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Chronic anal fissures manifest with a non-healing tear and high resting pressure of the internal anal sphincter, leading to ischemia and pain. Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the definitive treatment for patients unresponsive to conservative measures, as it reduces sphincter tone by surgically dividing a portion of the internal sphincter. This decreases resting pressure, improves blood flow, and promotes healing. The presence of granulation tissue indicates chronicity, supporting the need for this surgical intervention.

Key learning point: Lateral internal sphincterotomy is the preferred surgical treatment for chronic anal fissures when conservative management fails, as it reduces sphincter pressure and promotes healing.

B) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhoidectomy is indicated for hemorrhoidal disease, not chronic anal fissures. The patient presents with a posterior midline tear and high sphincter tone, characteristic of a fissure. Hemorrhoidectomy would not address the ischemia and impaired healing associated with the fissure, as there is no evidence of hemorrhoidal disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Botulinum toxin temporarily reduces sphincter hypertonicity by inhibiting acetylcholine release, offering short-term relief. However, its effects are transient, requiring repeat injections and leading to higher recurrence rates. In chronic fissures with persistent symptoms, a more durable reduction in sphincter pressure is needed, making botulinum toxin suboptimal.

D) INCORRECT:

Anal stretching involves manual dilation to reduce sphincter spasm but lacks precision and control. It carries risks of overstretching and incontinence. In chronic fissures with high sphincter tone, precise reduction of sphincter pressure is necessary, making anal stretching inappropriate due to its unpredictability and potential complications.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman presents to the clinic with severe rectal pain during bowel movements that lasts for hours afterward. She reports bright red streaks on toilet paper, anal itching, and recent constipation. Examination reveals a small tear at the posterior midline of the anal canal with marked tenderness but no fluctuance.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombosed external hemorrhoids cause acute anal pain and bleeding but typically present as a tender, bluish, edematous perianal mass at the anal margin, not as a linear tear. The examination describes a small tear at the posterior midline without a palpable mass, inconsistent with thrombosed external hemorrhoids.

B) INCORRECT:

Perianal abscesses present as tender, fluctuant masses with possible systemic infection signs. The examination notes a small tear with significant tenderness but no fluctuance, indicating no purulent collection. The history of severe pain and bright red blood suggests a mucosal injury rather than an abscess.

C) CORRECT:

Anal fissures manifest as linear tears in the anoderm, causing sharp pain during and after defecation. They commonly occur in the posterior midline due to poor blood supply, making the area susceptible to ischemic injury, especially with chronic constipation. Passage of hard stools can lead to a tear, resulting in bright red blood on toilet paper, local irritation, and itching. The examination finding of a small tear with marked tenderness aligns with this diagnosis. Management includes dietary fiber, stool softeners, sitz baths, and topical analgesics to promote healing and reduce pain.

Key learning point: Anal fissures typically present with sharp pain during and after bowel movements and anal itching, distinguishing them from other anorectal conditions.

D) INCORRECT:

Rectal prolapse involves protrusion of a full-thickness rectal segment, appearing as a concentric mass with radial folds. It is often seen in older patients with chronic straining. The examination reveals a small tear with marked tenderness, not protruding tissue, aligning more with a focal mucosal injury than rectal prolapse.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with severe anal pain that begins during defecation and continues for several hours afterward, described as sharp and throbbing. She has noticed bright red blood on the toilet paper. Inspection reveals a small tear in the posterior midline of the anal canal, and digital rectal examination is extremely painful. There are no fluctuating masses.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

An anal fissure is a small, linear tear in the anoderm, commonly located in the posterior midline of the anal canal due to poor blood supply and increased local pressures. It manifests with intense, sharp pain during and after defecation, attributed to the high density of pain fibers in the anoderm and reflexive internal anal sphincter spasm. Bright red blood on toilet paper indicates minor bleeding from exposed submucosal vessels. The clinical findings of a posterior midline tear, pain pattern, and minimal bleeding are characteristic of anal fissures.

Key learning point: Severe perianal pain post defecation with persistent sharp pain and fresh bleeding is characteristic of an anal fissure.

B) INCORRECT:

Perianal abscesses cause significant pain and typically present with a fluctuant mass and signs of localized infection, such as erythema and fever. The absence of a fluctuating mass and systemic signs, along with the presence of an anal tear, suggests a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Pilonidal cysts are subcutaneous infections in the sacrococcygeal region, presenting with a painful, fluctuant mass. The described small tear in the posterior midline of the anal canal with severe pain during defecation and bright red blood indicates a mucosal issue, not a subcutaneous infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Thrombosed external hemorrhoids present with anal pain and bright red blood but are characterized by a tender, swollen, bluish mass on the perianal skin due to thrombosis of an external hemorrhoidal vein. The absence of a fluctuating mass and the presence of a midline tear suggest a mucosal defect, not a vascular lesion.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of anal pain during defecation that persists for several hours afterward. She reports frequent straining during bowel movements and notes bright red blood on toilet paper after wiping. She typically has 3 bowel movements per week. On examination, there is a longitudinal perianal tear. Which one of the following locations is the most likely site of tissue injury causing her symptoms?

choices.text: Posterior midline of the anal canal, proximal to the pectinate line.
Lateral aspect of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line.
Posterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line.
Anterior midline of the anal canal, proximal to the pectinate line.
Anterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The region of the anal canal proximal to the pectinate line is a common location for internal hemorrhoids, whereas anal fissures occur distal to the pectinate line. Internal hemorrhoids are characterized by passage of bright red blood per rectum with a bowel movement. However, defecation is usually painless.

B) INCORRECT:

External hemorrhoids arise below the pectinate, often occur at the left lateral aspect of the anal canal (3 o' clock position), are typically painful, and can cause per rectal bleeding. However, external hemorrhoids would be visible as perianal swellings on physical examination. Less than 1% of anal fissures occur at the lateral aspect of the anal canal. Anal fissures that occur at this location are usually secondary to anal surgery, IBD (e.g., Crohn disease), infections (e.g., syphilis) or malignancy (leukemia). There is no evidence of an underlying condition in this patient that would that would make an anal fissure at an atypical location likely.

C) CORRECT:

Approximately 90% of anal fissures occur at the posterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line (dentate line). The etiology is usually benign and primary in nature, with the most common cause being local trauma (e.g., passing of hard stools due to constipation), persistent diarrhea, vaginal delivery, or anal sex. This predilection for the posterior midline is likely due to poor perfusion to this area. Acute anal fissures typically resolve with conservative management.

Key learning point: Anal fissures most commonly occur at the posterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate (dentate) line, typically due to local trauma from hard stools.
Image Description:

A longitudinal section of the anal canal with typical features of an acute anal fissure. A longitudinal tear in the anoderm extending from the dentate line to the anocutaneous line can be seen. The wound margins are smooth, and the surrounding mucosa appears unremarkable.

D) INCORRECT:

The region of the anal canal proximal to the pectinate line is a common location for internal hemorrhoids and adenocarcinoma of the anal canal, whereas anal fissures occur distal to the pectinate line. Internal hemorrhoids are characterized by the passage of bright red blood per rectum with a bowel movement. However, defecation is usually painless.

E) INCORRECT:

Only 10% of anal fissures occur at the anterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line. Anal fissures at this location are usually secondary to anal surgery, IBD (e.g., Crohn disease), infections (e.g., syphilis) or malignancy (leukemia). There is no evidence of an underlying condition in this patient that would make an anal fissure at an atypical location likely.
questions.hint: The region of tissue injury in this patient receives innervation from the inferior rectal branch of the pudendal nerve.

He also reports noticing small amounts of bright-red blood on the toilet paper after wiping. He denies abdominal pain, diarrhea, blood in the toilet bowl, or any history of anal trauma. On examination, you observe a superficial linear tear in the posterior anal midline. Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Botulinum toxin injection into the anal sphincter.
Mesalamine suppositories and a low-residue diet.

D) INCORRECT:

Mesalamine suppositories and low-residue diet are used to manage inflammatory bowel disease, not anal fissures.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical referral is reserved for patients in whom conservative measures fail.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a 5-day history of severe perianal pain that began after passing a hard stool. She describes the pain as sharp and tearing, occurring during and for several hours after bowel movements. She reports bright red blood on toilet paper and has been avoiding defecation due to fear of pain, resulting in worsening constipation. Physical examination shows a longitudinal mucosal tear in the posterior midline of the anal canal. She has no fever, and the surrounding perianal skin appears normal without induration or fluctuance. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Botulinum toxin injection into the internal anal sphincter
Oral antibiotics and warm sitz baths
Anoscopy to rule out underlying pathology
Immediate surgical consultation for lateral internal sphincterotomy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Botulinum toxin injection is a minimally invasive treatment option for chronic anal fissures that are refractory to conservative management. It is not the first-line therapy for acute fissures and is typically reserved for patients who have not responded to medical management.

B) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics are not indicated for uncomplicated anal fissures, as they are not infectious conditions. While sitz baths provide supportive care, antibiotics do not address the underlying pathophysiology of increased anal sphincter tone.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's acute anal fissure in the typical posterior midline location should be managed conservatively with topical calcium channel blockers, such as diltiazem, which reduce internal anal sphincter pressure and improve blood flow to promote healing. Stool softeners prevent further trauma by reducing the need to strain during defecation.

D) INCORRECT:

Anoscopy is indicated when an anal fissure is not easily visualized or has atypical features. This patient has a clearly visible fissure in the typical posterior midline location with classic symptoms, making anoscopy unnecessary at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical intervention is reserved for chronic fissures that are refractory to conservative management after 8–12 weeks. Since this patient’s fissure is acute (5 days), medical management is the initial approach, as most acute fissures heal without surgery.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with a two-week history of severe rectal pain during and after bowel movements. She describes the pain as 'sharp and tearing' and notes it can persist for up to an hour following defecation. She also reports seeing a small amount of bright red blood on the toilet paper. Her medical history is unremarkable. On examination, a single, linear tear is visualized in the posterior midline of the anoderm. A digital rectal examination is deferred due to severe patient discomfort. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Administer botulinum toxin injection into the internal anal sphincter
Increase dietary fiber, use stool softeners, and take sitz baths

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Injecting botulinum toxin into the internal anal sphincter induces a temporary chemical sphincterotomy, which can promote fissure healing. While it is a therapeutic option, it is considered a second or third-line treatment for chronic anal fissures that have failed first-line management. It is not an appropriate initial step for an acute fissure.

B) INCORRECT:

While anoscopy can be used to evaluate the anal canal, it is not indicated as the initial step here. The diagnosis is clinically evident from the history and visualization of the posterior midline tear. Furthermore, given the patient's severe pain, which already precluded a digital rectal exam, attempting anoscopy would be excessively painful.

C) CORRECT:

The pathophysiology of annal fissures involves a tear in the anoderm, often caused by hard stool, leading to a cycle of pain, internal anal sphincter spasm, and ischemia that prevents healing. First-line management is conservative and aims to break this cycle. Increasing dietary fiber and fluid intake, along with stool softeners (e.g., docusate), softens the stool to minimize trauma during defecation. Warm sitz baths, taken for 10-15 minutes after bowel movements, help relax the spastic internal anal sphincter, which reduces pain and increases blood flow to the fissure to promote healing. This conservative approach successfully heals most acute fissures.

D) INCORRECT:

Lateral internal sphincterotomy is a highly effective surgical procedure for anal fissures. However, it is reserved for chronic fissures that are refractory to both conservative and medical therapies. Given the acute two-week history, initiating treatment with an invasive surgical procedure is inappropriate and carries unnecessary risks, such as fecal incontinence.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is typical of an anal fissure.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents with a week of sharp anal pain that worsens with bowel movements and occasionally produces bright red blood on toilet paper. He has been taking warm sitz baths and using stool softeners without relief. He is otherwise healthy. Examination reveals a small tear at the posterior midline.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Botulinum toxin injection into the anal sphincter

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anal fissures result from mechanical trauma and internal anal sphincter hypertonia, leading to reduced blood flow and impaired healing. Topical diltiazem, a calcium channel blocker, reduces sphincter tone, enhancing blood flow and promoting healing. This approach is effective after conservative measures like sitz baths and stool softeners fail, as it addresses the underlying pathophysiology of sphincter spasm and ischemia.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for an acute anal fissure is chemical sphincterotomy with topical diltiazem, which helps relax the internal anal sphincter and promote healing.

B) INCORRECT:

Surgical lateral internal sphincterotomy is reserved for chronic anal fissures unresponsive to conservative treatment. It carries risks such as incontinence. This patient has an acute fissure, which usually responds to less invasive treatments like topical agents.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical hydrocortisone cream has anti-inflammatory properties but does not address the sphincter spasm and ischemia underlying anal fissures. It may impede healing by thinning tissues and is more suitable for inflammatory skin conditions, not for promoting healing in anal fissures.

D) INCORRECT:

Botulinum toxin reduces sphincter spasm and improves blood flow, but it is typically reserved for chronic or refractory anal fissures. This patient has an acute fissure, and initial management should focus on topical agents like diltiazem or nitrates.
